description.narrative: The goal of the proposed programme is to mitigate the consequences of Covid-19 on the health system with provision of essential health commodities to ensure the continuation of essential health services delivery in 4 provinces of Zambia. The programme is intended to promote resilience of the health system as a mitigation for Covid-19 impact by ensuring essential health commodity security especially focused on vaccines, essential medicines and supplies for reproductive, maternal, newborn, child and adolescent health services. The aim is to serve an estimated 1 million people with primary health care services, 375 000 infants with routine vaccination services and 380 000 pregnant women with maternal health supplies. The programme will also procure and distribute personal protective equipment, oxygen concentrators and infection prevention supplies for 5 000 health workers to avoid Covid-19 infection and ensure a healthy and safe work environment. The supplies are estimated to serve patients for a period of 6 months but the programme duration will be 1,5 years to ensure consistent monitoring, oversight and follow-up as well as capacity-building. More specifically, the key results will be: - 375 000 infants and 380 000 pregnant women across the country received routine immunisation services with traditional vaccines (BCG, tetanus/diphteria, polio vaccine and measles/rubella). - 1 000 000 people accessing curative services including RMNCAH care in 983 primary health care facilities and 48 hospitals in 4 provinces for 6 months. - 5 000 health workers in 983 primary health care facilities and 48 hospitals are fully equipped with PPEs for 2 months.

description.narrative:
The programme was designed to mitigate the consequences of COVID-19 on Zambias health system by directly addressing the health commodity security for essential medicines and vaccines and protecting health care workers from infection, including operational support to outreach services and last mile distribution of supplies. Support is also directed at coordination, planning and response to COVID-19 and to the entire health system in general. These interventions aim at mitigating the disruption of delivery of essential health services due to the potential increase in patient caseload resulting from the aggressive community transmission of COVID-19 and high infection rates among health care workers if unprotected.
The programme was created swiftly and designed as support to the broader multi-sectoral COVID response in Zambia and has had to be flexible to quickly adapt to the changing and unpredictable nature of the circumstances surrounding the pandemic. Programme implementation experienced some delays in the procurement and delivery of critical offshore supplies due to disrupted global markets and the global supply chain as most of the countries from where UNICEF procures supplies were in complete lockdown and cargo airlines were mostly not operational. With support from UNICEFs Supply Division in Copenhagen, UNICEF Zambia negotiated with the manufacturers and freight forwarders to prioritise and address the supply lines for Zambia. Despite these efforts, programme implementation continued to be challenged by delayed shipments due to inconsistently operating international cargo flights for air-shipment of critical offshore supplies.
In light of the above, good results have nevertheless materialized during the first 10 months:
i) A total of 366,743 infants and 252,466 pregnant women received routine immunisation services across 10 provinces in the country, with vaccine security ensured for four traditional vaccines (BCG, bOPV, Td and MR) for the entire nation for a duration of six months.
ii) Half a million (591,532) Zambians accessed continued essential curative treatment and RMNCAH services in the four SIDA-funded RMNCAH provinces with delivery of 19 priority itemised essential RMNCAH drugs and 983 units of basic module, 48 units of supplementary medicines module and 48 units of supplementary medical renewable module Interagency Emergency Health Kits (IEHKs).
iii) Over 5,000 health workers delivering essential health services across 1,031 health facilities (Eastern-314, Southern-347, Luapula-231, Muchinga-139) were equipped with PPEs and IPC supplies, to provide protection from COVID-19 infection.
iv) The health systems capacity for critical care for COVID-19 treatment was improved through the rehabilitation of three oxygen plants and procurement and supply of critical oxygen equipment such as, 50 double flow oxygen concentrators, 50 oxygen cylinders, 50 double outlet regulator flowmetres, and 50 low pressure oxygen gauges.
v) Improved cold chain capacity for vaccine management through the procurement of one Walk in Cold Room (WiCR) and 22 refrigerators for the four RMNCAH provinces.
